question: Question 1-09/05/2002 Given a source strength of 100 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor of 0.8, the expected neutron count rate would be:

answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 2-09/05/2002 With the reactor critical at 10 KW a rod is pulled to insert a positive reactivity of 0.00126 K/K. Which one of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this reactivity insertion?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: 49.5 seconds
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: 49.5 seconds
Incorrect. REF: 49.5 seconds

question: Question 3-09/05/2002 An initial count rate of 100 is doubled five times during a startup. Assuming an initial Keff of 0.950, which one of the following is the new Keff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2) or M1 (1-Keff1) = M2 (1 - Keff2) CR2/CR1 = 32  CR1 (1-Keff1)/CR2 = 1 - Keff2)  100 (1-0.950)/3200 = 1 - Keff2 Keff2 = 1 - .0015625 = .998
Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2) or M1 (1-Keff1) = M2 (1 - Keff2) CR2/CR1 = 32  CR1 (1-Keff1)/CR2 = 1 - Keff2)  100 (1-0.950)/3200 = 1 - Keff2 Keff2 = 1 - .0015625 = .998
Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2) or M1 (1-Keff1) = M2 (1 - Keff2) CR2/CR1 = 32  CR1 (1-Keff1)/CR2 = 1 - Keff2)  100 (1-0.950)/3200 = 1 - Keff2 Keff2 = 1 - .0015625 = .998
Correct.

question: Question 4-09/05/2002 Consider two identical critical reactors, with the exception that one has a beta of 0.0072 and the other has a beta of 0.0060. Each reactor is operating a 10 watts. Which one of the following compares the response of the reactors to a +0.1% delta k/k reactivity insertion?

answers.answer: a. The resulting period will be shorter for the reactor with the 0.0072 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: b. The resulting period will be shorter for the reactor with the 0.0060 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. The resulting power level will be higher for the reactor with the 0.0072 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: d. The resulting power level will be higher for the reactor with the 0.0060 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

question: Question 6-09/05/2002 The reactor is critical and increasing in power. Power has increased from 20 watts to 80 watts in 60 seconds. How long will it take at this rate for power to increase from 0.080 KW to 160 KW?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: P = P_0*e^t/T  80 = 20*e^60sec/T  T = 43.28 sec 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80*e^t/43.28 t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes
Incorrect. REF: P = P_0*e^t/T  80 = 20*e^60sec/T  T = 43.28 sec 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80*e^t/43.28 t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: P = P_0*e^t/T  80 = 20*e^60sec/T  T = 43.28 sec 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80*e^t/43.28 t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes

question: Question 7-09/05/2002 A reactor with an initial population of 24000 neutrons is operating with Keff = 1.01. Of the CHANGE in population from the current generation to the next generation, how many are prompt neutrons?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: PSTR Training Manual, Section 2.9 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added 240 neutrons added - 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added
Correct.

Incorrect. REF: PSTR Training Manual, Section 2.9 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added 240 neutrons added - 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added

Incorrect. REF: PSTR Training Manual, Section 2.9 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added 240 neutrons added - 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added

question: Question 8-09/05/2002 Which one of the following conditions would INCREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Inserting an experiment adding positive reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: b. Lowering moderator temperature if the moderator temperature coefficient is negative.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: c. Depletion of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.
Correct.

question: Question 9-09/05/2002 Which one of the following is the PRIMARY reason that delayed neutrons are so effective at controlling reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons make up a very large fraction of the fission neutrons in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons have a much longer mean lifetime than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons are born at thermal energies.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

question: Question 10-09/05/2002 Which one of the following is the principal source of heat in the reactor after a shutdown from extended operation at 1 MW?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

answers.answer: b. Kinetic energy of fission fragments
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.
Correct.

question: Question 12-09/05/2002 Following 8 hours at 1 MW, the reactor operator reduces reactor power to 50%. Rod control is placed in manual mode and all rod motion is stopped. Which one of the following describes the response of reactor power, without any further operator actions, and the PRIMARY reason for its response?

answers.answer: a. Power increases due to the burnout of xenon.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: b. Power increases due to the burnout of samarium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: c. Power decreases due to the buildup of xenon.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. Power decreases due to the buildup of samarium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

question: Question 13-09/05/2002 Which one of the following is a correct statement concerning the factors affecting control rod worth?

answers.answer: a. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth for periphery rods to decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: b. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth to increase in the center of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: c. The withdrawal of a rod causes the rod worth of the remaining inserted rods to increase.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. As Rx power increases rod worth increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

question: Question 14-09/05/2002 Pool temperature increases by 20F. Given Tmoderator = -0.0005 K/K/F and an average regulating rod worth of 0.004 K/K/inch. By how much and in what direction did the regulating rod move to compensate for the temperature change?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = - 0.01 K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Incorrect. REF: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = - 0.01 K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Incorrect. REF: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = - 0.01 K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Correct.

question: Question 15-09/05/2002 Which ONE of the following statements describes the subcritical reactor response as K_eff approaches unity?

answers.answer: a. A LARGER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a SHORTER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: b. A LARGER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a LONGER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. A SMALLER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a SHORTER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: d. A SMALLER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a LONGER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

question: Question 16-09/05/2002 An experiment to be placed in the central thimble has been wrapped in cadmium. Which one of the following types of radiation will be most effectively blocked by the cadmium wrapping?

answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.

question: Question 17-09/05/2002 A thin foil target of 10% copper atoms and 90% atoms aluminum is in a thermal neutron beam. Given s Al = 3.79 barns, s Cu = 0.23 barns, a Al = 7.90 barns and a Cu = 1.49 barns, which ONE of the following reactions has the highest probability of occurring? A neutron ...

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.

question: Question 18-09/05/2002 The reactor is operating at 500 KW in steady-state and in manual mode. Which one of the following describes the stable reactor period if a control rod drops fully into the core and no operator action is taken?

answers.answer: a. -34 seconds due to the rapid decrease in prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: b. -34 seconds due to the rapid decay of the short lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: c. -80 seconds due to the slowing down length of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: d. -80 seconds due to the decay half life of the long lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 19-09/05/2002 Which one of the following factors in the six factor formula is the most strongly affected by the Negative Temperature Coefficient ?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
